title: A long-term survey on anthropogenic impacts to the water quality of coral reefs, southern Taiwan

affiliation.institution: National Museum of Marine Biology & Aquarium
National Museum of Marine Biology & Aquarium
National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology

abstract: Before 2001, the ecological protection area in the Kenting National Park (KTNP), southern Taiwan, was poorly described. In this study, a set of four-year data (2001e2004) of seawater qualities at 19 sampling sites around the Nanwan Bay in the KTNP was used to explore anthropogenic impacts to ecological environment, especially coral reefs. The parameters of water quality were analyzed immediately after collection. The results showed that higher values of nutrients and suspended solids were attributed to the higher runoff around Nanwan Bay. The fluxes of nutrients and suspended solids were consistently correlated to rainfall. Hence, equations were developed to calculate nutrient fluxes and suspended solids by using only rainfall data. Our results show that suspended solids and ammonia were the dominant factors leading to the drop in coral coverage. In summary, the water quality in the intertidal zone of Nanwan Bay has been degraded and required greater attention.

abstract.text: Before 2001, the ecological protection area in the Kenting National Park (KTNP), southern Taiwan, was poorly described. In this study, a set of four-year data (2001e2004) of seawater qualities at 19 sampling sites around the Nanwan Bay in the KTNP was used to explore anthropogenic impacts to ecological environment, especially coral reefs. The parameters of water quality were analyzed immediately after collection. The results showed that higher values of nutrients and suspended solids were attributed to the higher runoff around Nanwan Bay. The fluxes of nutrients and suspended solids were consistently correlated to rainfall. Hence, equations were developed to calculate nutrient fluxes and suspended solids by using only rainfall data. Our results show that suspended solids and ammonia were the dominant factors leading to the drop in coral coverage. In summary, the water quality in the intertidal zone of Nanwan Bay has been degraded and required greater attention.

body_text.text: The negative impacts on the coastal environment of the Nanwan Bay, southern Taiwan, have increased dramatically due to human activities associated with population expansion and urbanization, such as modern agricultural practices, ill-conceived developments, deforestation, and soil erosion. Further, untreated and/or treated municipal wastes are often dumped directly into the nearby river-system. Excessive city sewage, chemical fertilizers and pesticides, as well as all kinds of human wastes are carried into the coastal waters. These inputs add to the large amounts of organic materials from cities already polluting most of the downstream rivers discharging into the Nanwan Bay, some of which are contaminated with chemicals and suspended sediment from various tourism operations.

The Kenting National Park, including the landmass area and nearshore waters, is located at the southernmost tip of Taiwan (Fig. 1) . The nearshore water region, locally known as the Nanwan Bay, supports one of the highest marine biological diversities within Taiwan. The beautiful landscape of the bay attracts many tourists, which has led to an explosion in tourism. In response to the rapid expansion of tourism, there has been an increase in farmland destruction along the Kenting coast to accommodate architectural constructions such as large hotels. This in turn has led to an increase of domestic wastewaters, some of which will discharge into Nanwan Bay without being treated during periods of heavy rainfall. These untreated inputs along with treated municipal wastes are often dumped directly into nearby creeks which carry excessive nutrient sewage, chemical fertilizers and pesticides into the coastal waters. The Nanwan Bay is also being polluted by excessive suspended sediments during high rainfall events. These sediments could bury coral reefs and benthic organisms, and therefore devastate the local fauna (Bastidas et al., 1999; Riegl et al., 1996; Thomas et al., 2003) . Determining how to monitor the settling rate of suspended particles on coral reefs is therefore a primary goal for biologists (Thomas, 2003; Thomas and Ridd, 2005) . In addition, the coastal area of the Kenting National Park is threatened by the warm effluent water from Nuclear Power Plant, which led to coral bleaching (Huang and Hung, 1987; Hung et al., 1989; Su et al., 1987 Su et al., , 1989 and negative impacts to the marine biological community (Chou et al., 2004) . Furthermore, cold-water intrusion onto the shelf during spring tides (Lee et al., 1997 (Lee et al., ,1999a , typhoons and unknown coral infection, subject the coral reefs within the park to serious risk. High environmental variability along coast places further challenges to survival for the coral reef ecosystem (Hodgson, 1990; Riegl and Branch, 1995; Umar et al., 1998; Rosemond et al., 2002) . Thus, to prevent continual coral reef degradation, determining the complex mechanisms responsible is extremely important.

To evaluate the coastal environments and coral reef ecosystem of the Nanwan Bay, we have monitored several hydrological, chemical, biological, ecological and geological parameters on the rivers, estuaries and coastal environments in the Nanwan Bay since 2001. The parameters included non-biological factors such as nearshore ocean currents, physical and chemical properties of seawater, and biological factors such as primary productivity, specific compositions and interspecific relationships among phytoplankton and zooplankton, algae, invertebrates, corals and fishes. Historical data collected from past years along the coast of the Nanwan Bay indicate that the nutrients, aerobic organisms and suspended particles come mainly from landmass effluent via channels or creeks. The rainfall data from Taiwan Central Weather Bureau at Kenting National Park area indicates that the wet season is from May to September and the dry season is from October to April, except for occasional heavy rain during dry season. The present study was aimed at collecting data on rainfall, stream fluxes and polluted material concentration from the past four years, but also included preliminary estimates on the fluxes of nutrients and suspended sediments from the main streams using the relationship among three factors. The results indicate that the influences of nutrients, aerobic organisms and suspended sediments contributing to the bay after mixing and dilution are negligible, even during the wet season. Further investigations should be conducted on determining how mixing and dilution of polluted materials prior to entering the Bay influence the potential for negative impacts. The present paper attempts to introduce the water quality for marine environmental monitoring and reports the recent monitoring results with emphasis on the coral reefs monitoring program along the Nanwan Bay.

Although a few chemists from universities control their quality of marine environmental monitoring using foreign QA/QC methods, the governmental QA/QC system, set up by EPA/China (Taipei), has been regulated since 1987. Beginning in 1987, the quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC) system and high standards of laboratory practices for environmental monitoring were established in our laboratory. The procedures and frequency used for periodic calibration of the equipment in monitoring must be specific. Calibration practice includes initial calibration, routine calibration, and specific calibration. In general, the governmental QA/QC system (Hung, 1987; Yang, 1987) including the sampling techniques, sample handling, laboratory services, glassware and analytical performance (such as control charts), is modified from the systems of USEPA (1979) , principles of environmental analysis (CEI/ACS, 1983) and of QA/QC for analytical laboratory (AOAC, 1984) . For the Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) monitoring program, the specific QA/QC for sampling (UNEP, 1991) and high standards of laboratory practices for analytical performance (UNEP, 1990; NOAA, 1988) were also applied. The general QA/QC programs for our marine environmental monitoring are as follows.

We collected seawater samples around the Nanwan Bay from 19 different collection sites from July 2001 to September 2004. The exact positions of sampling sites were located by global position system (GPS; Fig. 1 ).

To assess the water quality at different locations around the Nanwan Bay, the water samples were collected with metal-free Niskin bottles onboard either a research vessel Ocean Researcher I or fishing boat. Immediately after collection, water samples were analyzed for hydrographical, chemical, and ecological parameters. Quality control for sampling equipment and for field measurement procedures, such as temperature, salinity, pH, and dissolved oxygen, were conducted following our governmental QA/QC regulations. The remaining water samples were preserved at 4 C and returned to the laboratory
P.-J. Meng et al. / Environmental Pollution 156 (2008)

for analysis of the following chemical and biomass parameters: temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved oxygen, BOD 5 , nutrients (as nitrite, nitrate and phosphate), ammonia, chlorophyll-a, suspended solids and turbidity for most monitoring programs. The QA/QC system includes a complete description of all the sample custody and chain-of-custody procedures, forms, documentation, and personnel responsibility necessary to ensure both scientific credibility and the legal defensibility of the data obtained from the samples involved in the project.

The investigations of coral coverage rate were described in detail by Tkachenko et al. (2007) . The results of QA analyses of sample for all the chemical parameters were investigated and shown in Table 1 . The procedures and frequency of periodic calibration of the equipment used in the monitoring must be specified. These included volumetric glassware, balance, pH meter, and reagent water. The purity and tractability of information, as well as purity verification procedures were included. Calibration might include initial calibration, routine calibration, and specific calibration.

The measurements of temperature and salinity were carried out with CTD instrument (Sea-Bird Model 19 plus) on the research vessel and/or by the EPA/ROC (Taipei) methods on fishing boats. The precision for temperature was AE0.05 C and the accuracy and precision for salinity were AE0.003 psu and AE0.023 psu, respectively. Dissolved oxygen was measured by the Winkler method with an accuracy of AE0.04 mg/L and a precision of AE1.2%. The precision and accuracy (recovery of spike standard glucose) of BOD-5 day measurements were AE2.38% and 98.3 AE 7.7%, respectively, and then check with the control chart.
body_text.section: Analysis of hydrographical parameters including dissolved oxygen and BOD

body_text.text: Immediately after collection, water samples were stored in a refrigerator at 4 C and returned to the laboratory for analysis of ammonia and nutrients (as nitrite, nitrate, phosphate and silicate).

In the analysis of nutrients, a Flow Injection Analyzer (FIA) and spectrophotometer (Hitachi model U-3000) were used to conduct analysis on ammonia, nitrate, nitrite, phosphate and silicate (Pai et al., 2001; Pai and Riley, 1994; Pai and Yang, 1990a,b) . Ammonia was determined by the indophenol blue spectrophotometric method. Nitrate was reduced to nitrite with cadmium reductor and nitrite was determined by diazoting with sulfanilamide and coupling with N-(1-naphtha)-ethylenediamine dihydrochloride. Phosphate was determined by molybdate-antimony method. Silicate was determined by silicomolybdate method, which was reduced by metal-oxalic acid solution. The precision and the MDL of ammonia, nitrite, nitrate, phosphate and silicate were AE3.8% and 0.71 mM, AE0.9% and 0.03 mM, AE5.0% and 0.10 mM, AE4.5% and 0.06 mM, and AE2.0% and 0.2 mM, respectively. Each analysis of nutrients was calibrated with duplicate, standard sample spiking and QA sample analysis. For example, the results of duplicate, standard sample spiking and QA samples analysis of phosphate were AE0.16%, AE4.1% and AE4.03% respectively.

We analyzed the recent status of water quality with the values of average and standard deviation, such as salinity, pH, dissolved oxygen, biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, turbidity, chlorophyll-a and ammonia-N along the coast of the Nanwan Bay from Jul. 2001 to Sep. 2004 (Fig. 2) . Low values of dissolved oxygen (as low as 3.53 mg/L) were observed, along with high values of biochemical oxygen demand (as high as 7.4 mg/L), in the water along the Bau-Li and Shir-Neou coastal areas. In general, high standard deviation values indicate unstable conditions of the water quality, which could be the result of anthropogenic impacts. On the other hand, a narrow standard deviation signifies more stable condition of water quality. The data indicates that the contents (such as nitrite-N, nitrate-N, phosphate-P and silicate-Si) in water collected along the coast of the Nanwan Bay varied with season and location. For instance, high pollutant values were generally observed at the estuary stations, particularly near river outlets (such as Bau-Li River, Kang-Kou River and Shir-Neou stream) immediately following heavy rain during wet season. High concentrations of nutrients, BOD 5 , suspended solids and turbidity were also found in the water collected along the Nanwan Bay effluent area, such as Caesar Park coast.
body_text.section: The data of basic parameters of water quality

body_text.text: Marine pollution is mainly influenced by river pollution. Therefore, the degree of pollution of the three main rivers draining into Kenting coastal area were thoroughly assessed by monitoring dissolved oxygen, BOD 5 , suspended solids and ammonia-N. The degree of stream pollution defined in this study was followed River Pollution Index (RPI) (Liou et al., 2003) . The results indicated that the percentage of rivers maintained in good condition in the Kenting National Park were 44.4% in 2003. However, about 38.8% were moderately polluted in 2003. In general, the degrees of pollution in the three main rivers discharging in the Nanwan Bay were between low pollution to moderate pollution (Fig. 3) . Anthropogenic nutrient enrichment can stimulate algal blooms (Gobler et al., 2002) . In February 2002, we found the first incidence of green tide caused by nutrient pollution along the Shir-Neou coastal area. The chlorophyll-a content of phytoplankton in water was extremely high (e.g., 339 mg/L, 15.3 mg/L and 3.84 mg/L in February 2002 , May 2002 and June 2002 . Therefore, the correlation between nutrients and the content of chlorophyll-a was further investigated. Extremely higher nutrients (such as nitrite, nitrate and phosphate), BOD , turbidity and chlorophyll-a concentration in the water were observed in the Shir-Neou coastal area compared to those in other coastal areas. Experimental data also indicated that accumulation of nutrients varied with different seasons. For instance, the higher nutrient content would be accumulated in the river water be-tween dry seasons, and the lower nutrient content would be diluted in river water between monsoonal seasons.
body_text.section: The degree of pollution in the streams discharging into the Nanwan Bay

body_text.text: Expectedly, nutrient values, turbidity and suspended solids were affected by rainfall and run-off around the Nanwan Bay. River discharge, fluxes of nutrients and suspended solids were all dependent on rainfall. Traditionally, the Flow interval method (Ryding and Rast, 1989 ) is used to calculate the fluxes of nutrients. Fig. 4a shows the relationship between the discharges of the Kang-Kou stream and the rainfall. A relatively consistent correlation was found between nutrient abundance in the water and rainfall, except at the high rainfall condition (Fig. 4b ). The drop of nutrient level at high rainfall was attributed to dilution effect. In the other words, rainfall will flush the nutrients concentrated on the stream floor into the bay, which increase in the concentration of nutrient detected. However, when the rainfall increases up to a level, the dilution effect will overturn the increase of nutrient level in waters. Therefore, we used the formulas determined from the relationship between nutrients, discharges and rainfall to calculate the annual fluxes of nutrients and suspended solid from river water to seawater along the Nanwan Bay (Fig. 5) . Generally, only rainfall data from Taiwan Central Weather Bureau, readily accessible over the internet, is needed to obtain the flux data of nutrients. It is a rapid, economical and convenient method to calculate the flux of nutrients from river water to seawater. Nutrient chemistry and budgets in marine ecosystems and coral reef communities have been widely studied (Redfield et al., 1963; Chen et al., 2001; Hedges et al., 2002; Holmes et al., 2001; Johannes et al., 1983; Lapointe, 1997; Miller et al., 1999; Morell et al., 2001; Tockner et al., 2002 impression is that nutrient fluxes in the Nanwan Bay are mainly influenced by river pollution. High concentrations of nutrients from river waters at the Kenting National Park and consequent nutrient enrichment have been inferred primarily from field observations. On the other hand, there is daily periodical upwelling during spring tides within the Nanwan Bay, which is a result of cyclonic eddy pumping caused by the combined effects of tidal flow and topography (Lee et al., 1999a,b) . Consequently, another source of nutrients derived from the upwelling into the Nanwan Bay was recognized (Chen et al., 2004) . In terms of estimating the increase of nutrient concentrations by river discharge in the Nanwan Bay, we obtained the net nutrient fluxes of the Shir-Neou Stream divided by the overall volume and area of the Nanwan Bay. The overall volume and area of the Nanwan Bay are approximately 2.07 Â 10 9 m 3 and 4.73 Â 10 7 m 2 , respectively, which were calculated from a high-resolution numerical model of 200 m by 200 m in horizontal resolution and 7.5 m in vertical resolution (model not shown). The average fluxes of NO eN, NO 2 e N, PO 4 eP derived from Shir-Neou Stream discharge into the Nan-wan Bay are approximately 2.11 Â 10 À4 , 1.58 Â 10 À5 , 2.66 Â 10 À5 kg/m 2 /year during 2001e2004, respectively, which are calculated by the formulas from the relationships between nutrients, discharges and rainfall. In the other words, in the Nan-wan Bay, the average daily increase in concentrations of NO 3 eN, NO 2 eN, PO 4 eP that were contributed by the Shir-Neou Stream discharge are 1.32 Â 10 À2 , 9.84 Â 10 À4 , 1.66 Â 10 À3 mg/L/day, respectively. Yet, the results also indicated that the average daily increase in concentrations of nutrients derived from upwelling loading (0.52 kg N/m 2 /yr or 3.23 Â 10 1 mg/L/day; personal communication with HJ Lee) were three orders of magnitude higher (2.45 Â 10 3 factor) than the anthropogenic-derived loading (2.11 Â 10 À4 kg/m 2 /year). The foregoing estimates presume that all river inputs distribute evenly in the entire Bay. In reality, river inputs are preferably retained in shallow reaches of the Bay where effects of pollution are expected to be much higher.
body_text.section: The magnitude of nutrients in water

body_text.text: The relationship between parameters of water quality and coral coverage rate were shown in Table 2 . There was significant correlation between salinity and nutrient concentrations in the water. This implies that the sources of nutrients were from streams around Nanwan Bay. Obviously, there was significant correlation between dissolved oxygen and pH in the water. This indicates that the effects of photosynthesis and respiration on pH by organism (such as phytoplankton and algae) in the water. A relatively consistent correlation was found between nutrient and ammonia concentrations in the water and BOD 5 . On the other hand, there was also significant correlation between nutrient and ammonia concentrations in the water and chlorophyll-a contents. As we mentioned before, an increase of domestic wastewaters which carry excessive nutrients will flow into Nanwan Bay without being treated leading to increases in chlorophyll-a content and BOD 5 . Effects of water quality (such as sediments, thermal stress and nutrients) on coral reef ecosystem have been widely studied (Crossland et al., 1984; Woolfe and Larcombe, 1999; Miller and Cruise, 1995; Gilmour, 1999; Nugues and Roberts, 2003; James et al., 2005; Bruno et al., 2007; Manzello et al., 2007; Liao et al., 2007) . Our results show that suspended solids and ammonia were the dominant factors leading to the drop in coral coverage.
body_text.section: The relationship between parameters of water quality and coral coverage rate

body_text.text: This study provides some water quality data sampled along the Nanwan coast after heavy rainfall, which had been collected during in both dry and wet seasons. Over the past 4 years beginning from 2001, a number of studies have estimated sediment and nutrient loads by integrating flow and nutrient concentrations obtained from the mouths of the three streams that carry terrestrial materials discharging into the Nanwan Bay. This paper is the first time to describe the interactions between water quality and corals near estuaries along the Nanwan Bay. These terrestrial materials by way of riverine plumes in their estuaries will be carried by tidal currents and winds, moving back and forth along Nanwan coast. These higher nutrient and sediments from stream plumes during heavy rainfall, especially occurring in the wet season, are mostly confined in shallow water zone. In light of sampled data, the results show that the higher nutrients, BOD 5 and suspended solids concentrations alongshore were found in Bau-Li, Kang-Kou and Shir-Neou estuarine waters compared with those to other coastal water.

Therefore, the coral reefs around the Nanwan Bay have been negatively affected by higher values of nutrients, BOD 5 , suspended solids and so on. In summary, the water quality of shallow water in the Nanwan Bay has been degraded, and actually has impacted on some corals (Tkachenko et al., 2007) . To our knowledge, some corals such as Acropora sp. and Pocillopra damicornis are dominant species in shallow water throughout the coast of the Nanwan Bay, because they prefer to live within 5 m of water depth (Vaz, 2000) . The episodic heavy rainfall in wet season increase flow flux and turbidity flux from streams to shallow reaches of the Bay. In terms of estimating the overall increase of nutrient concentrations by river discharge during heavy rainfall runoff from the three streams, including Bau-Li, Kang-Kou and Shir-Neou streams around the Nanwan peninsula, the results indicate that anthropogenic nutrient loads have negatively influenced on the survival of the shallow water corals from a long-term point of view due to degrading water quality of these estuaries. Actually, higher nutrients and suspended sediments have made the algae with abnormal growth in coral reefs (Tkachenko et al., 2007) , leading to the parts of shallow water corals being covered by algae and buried by sediments. Although sampled data also illustrate that concentrations of these terrestrial materials collected from stream catchments were diluted rapidly in offshore regions, higher nutrient concentrations still make the impacts in shallow water corals. Table 2 Correlation coefficients (R) between parameters of water quality and coral coverage rate Correlation coefficient (R) Coral coverage Temp.
